Award.AwardTitle: Exploring Fundamental Physics in the Early and Late Universe
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Mark P. Hertzberg at Tufts University.

Decades of research in both particle physics and cosmology have led us to a set of so-called "Standard Models" which provide tremendously successful descriptions of the universe over a vast range of energy and length scales. However, future revolutions in physics will arise from tackling the various shortcomings of these models. In particular, some of the greatest mysteries that remain concern the nature of dark matter, the details of early-universe cosmology, and a deep understanding of the structure of gravitation. Professor Hertzberg's research will tackle these subjects through the formulation of theoretical models and the exploration of connections to experiment and data. As a result, research in this area advances the national interest by promoting fundamental scientific research into the nature of the universe. Furthermore, this project is envisioned to have significant broader impacts as it will involve postdocs and engage the public in an important way through public lectures and popular articles.

More technically, Professor Hertzberg will investigate axion dark matter in galaxies, develop novel inflationary models that probe new physics, and investigate theories of spin-two particles. This involves the development of theoretical models that demand internal consistency and greement with data, all within the framework of effective field theory. The primary work on the dark-matter front is to determine the clumpiness, distribution, and possible evidence for axion dark matter. The primary work on the early-universe front is to determine if reasonable inflationary models exist that improve agreement with CMB data on large scales beyond the standard scale-invariant models. Finally, the primary objective on the gravity front is to determine if general relativity is the uniquely consistent effective theory of spin-two particles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our current set of laws of physics are summarized by the so-called standard model of particle physics and are embedded within the standard model of cosmology. These theories have been very successful in describing the universe on both large and small scales. However, they possess various problems, both theoretical and observational. This project tackled several concrete aspects of these problems, which are all at the interface of fundamental physics and cosmology. This included (a) axion dark matter, (b) models of inflation, (c) aspects of eternal inflation and Higgs physics, (d) new physics, and (e) connections between quantum gravity and dark energy. This resulted in numerous publications in highly respected journals.

On the topic of dark matter: The PI first examined the properties of gravitationally bound stars of one of the leading candidates for dark matter; the so-called axion. The PI performed a detailed stability analysis to determine under what conditions the stars are stable, for various kinds of configurations. The PI also investigated the idea that these stars can rapidly produce electromagnetic waves, due to a phenomenon known as parametric resonance. The PI determined the conditions under which this novel process can occur. This leads to interesting possibilities for detection, which is ongoing work.

The PI also investigated the timely issue of so-called ultra-light axions, as many authors have claimed they explain why the centers of galaxies are less dense than may be anticipated in simple models. The PI put this very popular claim in the literature to the test. The PI found that while an ultra-light particle will indeed lead to a less dense center, the specific relationship between the central density and thickness did not match for different galaxies. This suggests that the solution to this problem may involve other ideas or require improved simulations of existing models.

On the topic of early universe models of inflation: The PI developed models that lead to the formation of primordial black holes; these are a potentially interesting component of the dark matter. Furthermore, the PI also studied the fact that the so-called cosmic microwave background radiation, the afterglow of the big bang, has been seen to exhibit peculiar features on very large scales. A class of early universe inflation models was examined to see if it could fit the data, finding that it can, though significant tuning of the models is required.

On the topic of aspects of eternal inflation and Higgs physics: the PI began by systematically addresses the issue of the probability distribution associated with the value of the so-called Higgs field. This can have cosmological relevance: in the standard model of particle physics, if the Higgs field value is small in the early universe, then the Higgs will relax to our observed vacuum, however, if the Higgs field value is very large in the early universe, then it will not relax to our observed vacuum; it will lead to an instability. The PI obtained the probability distribution for this to occur, as a function of the so-called Hubble scale of the early universe, under some simplifying assumptions.

On the topic of new physics beyond the Standard Model: The PI began a preliminary investigation into truly natural models of dark matter, without the appeal to any unnecessary additional features. This led to well defined classes of models, involving strong dynamics in hidden sectors, which are akin to the strong force in the standard model. This led to models in good agreement with observations, although they require slightly low temperatures in order to have the correct dark matter abundance. Addressing the latter issue is ongoing work. 

On the topic of connections between quantum gravity and dark energy: there has recently been much attention on whether considerations from quantum gravity, especially string theory, constrain low energy physics so much to favor models of dark energy governed by a slowly evolving scalar field known as quintessence. The PI examined the issue of fine-tuning of the underlying microscopic models, including possible extra dimensions. The PI found that while there does appear to be some preference for elegant quintessence models classically, there is significant fine-tuning involved when quantum effects are taken into account.

Throughout this project the PI engaged in mentoring. Firstly, the PI guided a post-doc on this research, which has advanced their career. Secondly, the PI guided multiple graduate students and undergraduate students on thesis topics on this work. Moreover, the PI engaged in the dissemination of science outside Tufts University; giving numerous talks at other institutions, workshops, and conferences; leading discussions on scientific panels; travel to various parts of the US, as well as Europe, Asia, and Australia. Furthermore, the PI connected to different groups interested in aspects of cosmology, particle physics, and astronomy, furthering connections between these and general interest groups.
